The Ladies' Maid and the Hair Dresser—Like master, like man—Return of the Dancer—Disappointment and vexation from ill suecess, a
scene of real life The Ladies anger subdued by the unexpected appearance of a real lover—Sudden arrival of the Doctor, as sud den revival
of the L ady's health The Rival Lovers—Two of a trade can never agree—Departure of Florinda and the duel deferred.

THE ATTIC.

The Chevalier,
OTr.
"WALTON.
Michel Magnus.

Mariette,
Miss EMMA STANLEY.

Origin of making Actors favorites, whether the Public like it or no—Money does wonders under the rose—The rich seeking titles, and
the titled seeking riches—Never doubt servants 'till you find them "ut. then turn them out.

Was, on each representation, most enthusiastically received and
cheered throughout by brilliant, crowded, and fashionable audiences;
It will, therefore, be repeated, in consequence of the demand for places.
every Evening till the termination of the Season.

GRAND &, COMIC OPERAS

Original Operas: and English Versions of the best

who, being betrolhed, die before ilieir weddfug day, and are >uppo«eJ MI find no rest in the tomb ; for. though life has fled, there reoains ia
them an insatiable love of the danre. At midnight, and in the bright moonlight. Ikey rise in ciowds, arrayed in their bridal dresses, wreathed
with flowers and sparkling with jewels; their face., though pale, hare the beauly of youth, and winning smilea play upon their lips. Woe tothe young man whose evil destiny leads him within reach ot their perfidious fa-rinations ! He is compelled to join their wild orgies, and to
dance till, from .xhaaslinn. he sinks down and enpires.—HKHRV HBIN V. OH U t i m o r .

§**$&'
LESSEE of thi« Theatre beg. to state that. Injustice to
*<S*
himself and the G E N U I N E E N P A N S CASTELLI* the
following explanation is requisite. The Lessee, when at Paris, had
o tiered terms fOr Les Enfans Castelli to an Agent assuming the authority to make an engagement in their behalf. The terms were accepted,
and the Children were consequently announced to appear at this Theatre;
but when the contract was sent to London, in lieu of those w ho formed the,
troupe Castelli, being therein inserted, the Agent at Paris had substituted
the Twenl y-tour Children composing a small company lately performing a t a little Theatre in the Passage de 1* Opera, Paris, called the
Gy innate Enfantin, not in the remotest way connected with Les Enfans
Caatelli ; upon this, the contract was sent back -with a demand that the
origiaal agreement should be completed. The Agent at Paris having
failed to fulfil his treaty with the Leasee of ibis Theatre for the G E N U another ISslablswhinent.

_t^£~ The LESSEE of this THEATRE beg. to state that, in justice to
himsell and the G E N U I N E E N F A N S C A S T F L L L the
following explanation is requisite. The Leasee, when a t Paris, had
offered terms for Les Enf'ans Castelli to an Agent assuming the author i t y to make an engagement in their behalf. The terms w e r e accepted,
and the Children Mere consequently announced to appear at this Theatre;
but when the contract was sent to London. In lieu of those who formed the
troupe Castelli, being therein inserted, the Agent at Paris had substituted
the Twenty-four Children composing a small company lately performing a t a little Theatre in the Passage de I* Opera. Paris, called the
Gynmase Enfantin, not in the remotest w a y connected with Les Enfans
Castelli; upon this, the contract w a s sent bark with a demand that the
original agreement should be completed. The Agent at Paris having
falled to fulfil his treaty with the Leasee of ihis Theatre for the G E N U I N E ENJPANS C A S T E L L L has, it^appears engaged the Twentyfour C H I L D R E N O F T H E J U V E N I L E
G Y M N A S I U M »another Establishment.

T h e B a l l e t a r r a n g e d a n d p r o d u c e d h y Mr. 451XBKHT. T l i e O a n c e - by Ma (In m e VBOV.
S c e n e r y b y Mr, NICHOLS a n d A s . i . t a n t g . M a c h i n e r y b y M r . HAtfKKV .
P r o p e r t i e s b y Mr. KBL.IiY. T h e B r w t N b y M r . S S I T H E B * a n d M l . * I H K M Kl».

There ejisi, a legend iu 8rlaroaia of a nocturoal dance, umltr the name ut " The Danee of the Wilis."
The Wilis are young maidens
who, being betrothed, die before their wedding day, and are supposed to find no rest in the tomb ; for, though life ha* hVd, there remains i>
them an insatiable love of the dance. At niidui^hl,aiid m the bright nw*nligbt, tbey rmr incro«rin, arrayed in thrir bridal dresses, wreathed
with flowers and sparkling with jewels: tbeir face*, though pale, have the beauty of youth, and winning «milrs play upon their lips. Woe to
the young man wbo*e evil destiny leidshim within reach of their perfidious fascinations ! He is compelled to join their wild orgies, and to
dance till, front exhaustion, hesmksdown and expires.—HENRY H E I N F , ON GKSMANY.

MAID O F JUDAH.

MR. & MRS. WOOD

Were, on each appearance, honored by the enthusiastic applause or
a most fashionable, brilliant, and crowded audience. In consequence
of the immense succes* of these celebrated Vocalists, and the overflow to
every part of the Theatre,
